messages: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:56): Yay, IE9 pp3 *almost* correctly displays my SVG-and-javascript emulator for a flash game.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:56): It just messes up one of the SVGs for some reason, and won't animate them yet.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:57): Those are possibly related - the messed up one is the animated one.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:28): for those interested in e-books, and/or specifically in the ePub format -
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:28): http://www.idpf.org/idpf_groups/IDPF-EPUB-WG-Charter-4-27-2010.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:28): see the Preliminary Solutions section
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:29): where it lists "Adopt HTML5 Features"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:30): also see "Current Industry Problems" the list of problems that they are trying to address with this 2.1 update to ePub
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:30): e.g., "Need for enhanced global language support"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:31): and specific mention of "including but not limited to special line-breaking rules and vertical writing direction"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:31): "it is acknowledged that a number of significant issues would need to be resolved" i wonder what those are
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:32): dunno
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:32): but we can try to find out
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:33): they seem to be taking a fairly pragmatic approach to this update
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:33): so far

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:33): e.g., see the statement, "Since most distributed Reading Systems utilize Web browsers to present content to end users, and many standalone Reading Systems utilize Web browser rendering technologies in their implementations, it is desirable to improve alignment with Web standards as implemented by modern browsers."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:34): "as implemented"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:34): as opposed to, say, "as we would have preferred them to have been implemented"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:35): or "as not implemented yet but we will spec things out on the basis of blind faith"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:36): keep in mind that ePub 2.0 is normatively based on XHTML 1.1
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): they seem to have done a reasonable job overall of being pragmatic within the constraints of not being experts in web tech
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:36): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:37): and switching away from XHTML 1.1 to "as implemented in modern browsers" is a great move to start with, at least
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:38): anyway, vertical text support is extremely important for e-book-reading use cases in Japan
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:38): I am told it is for Taiwan also
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:38): though less so for mainland China
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:39): yup
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:39): Apple's version of ePub will (as I'm sure has been previously mentioned) allow arbitrary HTML5 constructs
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:39): and people have in fact used it to embed video and audio and such in books
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:39): which is neat
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:40): from what I hear, there are a number of language features important for books in east asian locales
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:40): and people are pickier about some of them for books than for web sites
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:40): if Apple ends up doing any of them of course we'll feed the work into WebKit so it will be there for websites too
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (22:41): but I think most of the east asian language issues are mostly CSS level questions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:42): the only two vertical text things i'm aware of for html5 are to do with canvas drawText and captions
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:42): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: yeah, I think for east-asian language/layout issues, it is mostly about CSS-level questions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:42): in canvas' case it's actually already specced, i just commented it out since it depends on CSS spec text that isn't yet written

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:42): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: and I will say that from what I see, people in Japan are definitely much pickier about language features for books than they are for websites
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:43): We're arguing about vertical-text stuff in the CSSWG right now anyway, spurred mostly by epub.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:43): in the case of subtitles it'll be similarly commented out once i'm done unless css has caught up, but it's already designed in
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:43): e.g., almost all books -- paperback books, mass-market everyday reading stuff -- uses vertical text
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:44): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: good to hear that the discussion is going on in the CSS WG
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:44): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: is Murakami-san from Antenna House in the gropu?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:44): the vertical text stuff was being discussed in the csswg 2000, too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:44): when i joined the group
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:44): He's an editor of one of the relevant specs, actually.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:44): we even went to CR once!
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:44): Yeah, the consensus is still sorta *shrug*.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:44): (and then took it back when fantasai didn't like it)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:46): well, Murakami-san can argue with some vehemence, for sure. But his an implementor. Not a browser implementor but anyway an implementor of a fairly complex and powerful application
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:47): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I guess it's not reasonable to expect everybody in the group to see vertical text as a hugely higher priority
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:48): maybe a lot of the work on driving it will end up coming from developers on the Chrome team in Japan
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:48): Well, we all want it.  The issue is *how*, because CSS in general contains a lot of assumptions that depend on horizontal text layout.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:48): I see

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:48): There's the IE approach, frex, where switching the writing mode to vertical just "rotates" everything, so that, for example, padding-top now adds padding to one of the horizontal sides.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:49): But most people in the group think that's stupid.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:50): "frex" is an odd choice of a name for that
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:50): frex = for example
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:50): I'm inconsistent in my usage of that word.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:50): didn't grok the abbreviation at first
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:50): I picked it up from some message board years ago and it's stuck in my head.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:51): just struck me in this case because in Japanese it's pronounced same as "flex"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:51): no difference in translitering "r" and "l"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:52): which is why I thought those freaking horn things were called "bubuzera"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:52): because that's what Japanese TV calls them
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:52): oh, no difference often between "b" and "v" too
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:52): The correct term is "vulvazookeepers".
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:53): So, back to technical talk.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:54): Another possible solution is to introduce logical-direction equivalents of every physical-direction property, so you can do padding-before, frex, and have it mean padding-top in horizontal writing and padding-left or whatever in vertical writing.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:55): This would work "automatically", but only in relatively limited circumstances where you're not adjusting the layout based on writing mode.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:55): It also doesn't solve related problems, like the fact that in japanese vertical writing an underline goes on the opposite side of what you'd expect.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:56): So a third possibility is to have some sort of selector or media query or whatnot that distinguishes between when a document/element is in vertical or horizontal mode and lets you apply arbitrary CSS to it.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:14): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: would seem like a good use for media queries
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:15): There are complications, but yeah, probably.
